awd_titl_txt: Conference: Child Language Acquisition Symposium for Indigenous Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The Indigenous Child Language Research Center (ICLRC) is hosting the Child Language Acquisition Symposium for Indigenous Communities (CLASIC) to support and grow language nest programs across the US and Canada, where infants, toddlers, and young children are immersed in an Indigenous language so that they are raised as fluent speakers. This two-day gathering fosters empirical research in partnership with language nests by creating cultural and educational opportunities for both Indigenous community members and linguistic researchers. CLASIC accomplishes this goal by virtue of its uniqueness as a conference that equitably brings together community language programs, the families of children who attend these programs, and those who may carry out research with these programs. The conference provides equal time and opportunity for each of these diverse stakeholders to speak to and be heard. Such dialogue should result in partnerships among language nests and between language nests and researchers.  

Very little acquisition research is done with Indigenous languages. This conference provides a venue for language nest representatives, parents, and linguistic researchers to have important discussions of how first language acquisition research and language revitalization initiatives among very young children can support one another. The conference supports a primary goal of ICLRC, which is to work in partnership with communities to ensure the vitality of child language acquisition of Indigenous languages and to disseminate knowledge on child language acquisition research in an ethical and responsible way. Additionally, conference discussion can identify empirically supported developmental paths for Indigenous language acquisition, inform language policy, and shape evidence-based curriculum. The unique research focus of CLASIC draws attention to first language acquisition among Indigenous communities, groups that have historically been underrepresented in child language research. This conference supports initiatives for Indigenous people to lead important child language acquisition research collaboratively and with their own communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Indigenous Child Language Research Center (ICLRC) at the University of New Mexico hosted the first gathering of the Child Language Acquisition Symposium for Indigenous Communities (CLASIC) on May 17-18, 2024. This event brought together child language researchers, linguists, and Indigenous community stakeholders dedicated to the important work of first language acquisition, reclamation, and revitalization. Over the course of two days, this conference featured panel discussions, research presentations, community presentations, and group discussions during shared meals.

CLASIC provided a platform to showcase some of the most recent studies on first language acquisition conducted by researchers working with Indigenous communities. This is significant because research on Indigenous languages, particularly those spoken in the United States and Canada, is scarce. Their work is crucial in addressing the gap in linguistic literature and advancing understanding of how research can aid in language revitalization efforts.

In addition to highlighting ongoing research, the conference showcased the voices of Indigenous parents and practitioners involved in language nests, recognizing their critical role in preserving and strengthening linguistic heritage. This event successfully engaged Indigenous communities, many of whom learned how research can inform their needs, such as identifying language-specific milestones, shaping curriculum and teaching methods, and improving overall health and well-being. We hope that this will inspire more Indigenous people to take part in using research as a tool to inform the important work being done within their own communities.

Throughout the conference, Indigenous community members and academic researchers were consistently impressed by each other’s efforts and interested in each other’s work. CLASIC fostered several tangible outcomes, including the formation of a professional network of language nests across the U.S. and Canada to provide mutual support and development, the creation of a reading group of academic linguists focused on Indigenous language acquisition research, and the establishment of initial working relationships between community members and researchers.

To share the knowledge generated at CLASIC, the ICLRC has published a proceedings booklet. This booklet contains presentation summaries, attendee demographic information, survey results about the attendee experience, and summaries of the group discussions that took place each day. A physical copy of the booklet was mailed to each group of presenters and is freely available to the public as a PDF in the University of New Mexico’s digital repository.

CLASIC has proven to be a groundbreaking event, fostering meaningful connections between Indigenous communities, language experts, and academic researchers. Currently, there are no other conferences we know of that focus on connecting language nests ensuring the transmission of Native languages and researchers who study how these languages are acquired in children, while also allowing them to share their work with one another to support community endeavors. CLASIC has filled this important gap, achieving significant and positive outcomes. The relationships formed and the knowledge shared during this event will continue to inspire and drive collaborative efforts in the future.
